comment: Chicken Rice is located next to the Resh Fruit stall at the entrance / exit of the Comtech foodcourt on level 1 / basement / same level as the carpark. Don't be fooled by the long queues, they move super fast. It's probably the fastest service you can experience at the Comtech Foodcourt. What I love most about this stall is that it is just decent chicken rice for $ 2,50. The portions of chicken are not to be complained about. The rice is full of chicken skin fat flavor. The spicy sauce is balanced and delicious. The dark sauce is as you expect it to be. The staff is very friendly. Good job guys, keep it up!

rest_name: Depot Road Zhen Shan Mei Claypot Laksa
comment: This is one of my favourite laksas in Singapore. The gravy is really lemak and is properly spicy, the way I like it. The claypot also adds a little extra oomph to the taste/overall laksa eating experience. The drawbacks are that the portion sizes are a bit small - I usually order medium - and they are a little stingy with ingredients. But maybe this is because I'm comparing the current standard to when the stall was still run by the father at the Depot Road location. I personally feel that the standard has dropped a bit since then. The other problem is that the parking is a little problematic at Bukit Merah as there are very few lots near the market. However, these are small complaints for me at the end of the day. I've still found myself coming back for more because this laksa really is that good.

rest_name: Depot Road Zhen Shan Mei Claypot Laksa
comment: The best Laksa, hands down. Served in a beautifulclaypot, this laksa is fresh and warm. There's just enough spice for it to be delicious without overwhelming. The noodles are tender, although the prawns and fish cake are nothing special. Still a top tier Singapore hawker meal - especially at $5.

rest_name: Depot Road Zhen Shan Mei Claypot Laksa
comment: Ok laksa... portion is quite little for the price though. Love that it's served in a claypot. Unique idea.

rest_name: Depot Road Zhen Shan Mei Claypot Laksa
comment: Nice and spicy laksa.  The soup itself is very tasty and spicy.  However, could use more stuff in the laksa.  More tofu? More shrimp?  Something to give it more texture, depth?

rest_name: Depot Road Zhen Shan Mei Claypot Laksa
comment: Nice clay pot laksa but the standard is not as good as it used to be when the stall location was in depot road.

rest_name: Depot Road Zhen Shan Mei Claypot Laksa
comment: I'm not the hugest fan of laksa mainly because I'm terrible at tolerating spicy food, but when something's good, I've just got to eat it, which explains my foray to katong for laksa from time to time. That was before I discovered Zhen Shan Mei, which is located much nearer to where I live. I used to get my convenient fix of laksa sitting on the stools inside Queensway Shopping Centre, in between a casual stroll looking around for sporty stuff. Now, a five minute walk across to Alexandra Village brings me to one of the most 'sedap' bowls of laksa you'll find in Singapore.Some may not like it this way, but I adore this because it's so thick, rich and a fairly oily, so it not only leaves me quite full, but also satisfied to last till my next craving. It always feels good to eat out of a claypot, so there's that factor to this too, but I believe it's the way it's warmed in claypots that brings out that flavour in the soup. I wouldn't note this for its spiciness, because I don't recall having that big a sweat eating this, but even if you crave the chilli you will surely still enjoy this! Just ask for added chilli on the side, perhaps.

This place does magical things with vegetables.I like salads but I'm not really a *salad person* but everything I had was just really freaking good.Like with one bite you suddenly realize how a pasta salad should be prepared and everyone else has just got it wrong, or you eat a avocado cucumber slaw that's so light and refreshing that you seriously wonder how this isn't a staple for all humankind.I like this place a lot. Playlist and garden feels also A+.Slight minus for the small space.

Rating is for their coffee & ambience. Ordered a flat white - rich and smooth, definitely one of the better ones I've tasted in Singapore & Bangkok. Small but really laid-back place to hang out in the afternoon. With al fresco (aka smoking) area. Don't miss out exploring Gillman Barracks while you're at it Didn't get to try their food but heard the Quinoa Goreng is fab, so will definitely be back to try that ;)

The Red Baron's a small cafe tucked away in a corner of Gillman Barracks. Half the menu was marked off, which left us with breakfast choices for lunch. Would have preferred the Yoghurty Buckwheat Pancakes without the Greek yoghurt, but the meal was satisfactory.

This is a review of Tapas 26 on Dempsey and not of 26 Tapas on Kendahar, which closed anyway. Tapas 26 is run by the same team that managed La Ventana, but it changed name and moved a  few houses away, to where The Disgruntled Chef used to be. The food is as good as what you would find  at the better tapas bars in Spain, and as scrumptious as FOC even if the décor and ambience is much more homey. But foodies should not get their hopes too high, this is still a long way from the now-defunct Catalunya though, but again Catalunya was unique - its pool of talented chefs and bartenders could helm many top restaurants anywhere. Incidentally, the suckling pig, while delicious, is not the best that Spain can give - you can't cut it with a plate!

address: 6 Jalan Bukit Merah #01-51 ABC Brickworks Market & Food Centre Singapore 150006 Singapore
comment: cheap is good, free is better.it is not free here but definitely cheap!$2.50/$3 will buy you a substantial and delicious bowl of fish ball or minced meat noodles.they open early and usually sell out by lunch time.be prepared to queue for this elderly hawker couple's fare.they were formerly at farrer rd.after the renovations there, most of the good hawkers left.and lao jian cheng is one of them.for some time, i was wondering where they went.then i chanced upon them at ABC and the rest is history.noodles here are always well cooked.their version is the vinegary teochew type.but no flat fish though.just a hearty bowl and a tasty cloudy broth.

address: Blk 119, Bukit Merah Lane 1 Singapore 151119 Singapore
comment: Checking out the hipster coffee shop in Bukit Merah again and this time round we are going for some German cuisine as well as seafood. We were quite lucky to have a seat with just walking-in and without any reservation.Serving mussels in broth of garlic and wine and all in one pot. The pot in its handle gave us a total feel as if we were at home and an additional bucket to arrange the empty shells into it.Mussels in Stock - $15Those mussels were fresh and just simply dip the toasted white breads into the sauce and finished up the dish!Hope to be back again for others seafood.

address: Blk 119, Bukit Merah Lane 1 Singapore 151119 Singapore
comment: One of the stalls in a coffee shop with affordable versions of restaurant-style western food. I tried the Mac and cheese as well as fried fish. The Mac and cheese have the right amount of thickness and flavours. I wanted the haddock fish but it was not available. I was recommended barramundi instead and it turned out great! The creamy salted egg sauce was delicious. The fish was fresh and the greens were appetizing. I peeked at other people's orders of grilled squid and they looked mouth-watering too. Thumbs up!

address: Blk 119, Bukit Merah Lane 1 Singapore 151119 Singapore
comment: Seasalt is a great seafood stop to come by after a trip to Ikea. I had the fresh mussels prepared in garlic cream sauce, which cost $16 and was very share worthy. Comes with three slices of French baguette bread.

address: Blk 119, Bukit Merah Lane 1 Singapore 151119 Singapore
comment: Best fish and chips in Singapore! Fish is soft and flaky on inside, crispy tasty batter on outside. Butter and lemon sauce is delicious. Highly recommend.

address: Blk 119, Bukit Merah Lane 1 Singapore 151119 Singapore
comment: Simple normal fish and chips which can be find anywhere n it expensive in tat area. Salad not very fresh also

address: 38 South Buona Vista Rd Singapore 118164 Singapore
comment: Went with my girlfriends last saturday. Having to look at instagram posts and menu, we noticed that they are popular for their black ink dishes. So we decided to order 黑 Rice, Black Sea, Crab Roll and Truffle fries to share.All of us love the 黑 Rice. From its presentation, decent proportion of the rice and the fried chicken as well as the egg. The rice tasted like Kampong Fried Rice with rich flavour. However, was quite confused as I didn't taste the black ink and it was just for the rice appearance. Overall, its a must order whenever anyone visit there, with the black ink taste or not. The crab roll was satisfactory as well. There was a lot of filling and the bun was crispy outside and soft inside, it was perfectly baked. The least favourite dish of the day was the Black Sea. Although I can taste the black ink in the pasta, however the seafood was undercooked as so it was tough to eat. The flavour was only decent and the portion size is very small. Truffle fries was great. Unlike most of the truffle fries out there, we can really smell and taste the truffle. In conclusion, the winner of the day is the 黑 Rice and I would gladly recommend it to my friends. While the crab roll was satisfactory, i think both the roll and black sea portion need to be improved as we are playing quite a lot for the dishes. At the end of the day I can only remember I was full because of the fries.Serving was good and the waitresses were attentive and full of smiles.

address: 38 South Buona Vista Rd Singapore 118164 Singapore
comment: After getting completely lost looking for this place, we were surprised to find a super cute cafe in the middle of (almost) nowhere. It's discreetly hidden amongst a row of shophouses so it's really cute.The service was a bit choppy - some servers were great and others were confused. I think if everyone had been a little more on top of things, I'd be a much happier customer!We got 3 things to share:1. Cauliflower fritters - decent with a nice dipping sauce but was a little too over fried, I think the cauliflower would have done equally well roasted and would have been even better and healthier2. Black rice with steak - really loved the texture of the rice which was bouncy and chewy and delicious with the Japanese mayo and tobiko! The steak was surprisingly juicy and not overcooked.3. Buccatini with thick cut bacon - this was disappointing, the sauce had no flavor (squid ink) and the bacon was really salty. The bacon however, did balance out the pasta which had no flavor. We agreed that this would have done better with udon rather than using a pasta.We had tea and coffee as well, all of which were fine but nothing stood out. I would go back if I lived/worked in the area, but wouldn't make a special trip.

address: 38 South Buona Vista Rd Singapore 118164 Singapore
comment: Paddy Hills offers unique dishes in a hip environment on the West side of Singapore. It can get very crowded on weekends, so I would recommend coming here for lunch during the week if you work on the west side!The unique spin on dishes here is definitely what makes Paddy Hills special. The Tonkatsu Ricotta, Salmon Dish, and Fish w/Potatoes were a few of my fav dishes. I am personally not a huge fan of potatoes but was very delighted to find theirs come in stringed shape, almost like noodles (see pic)Menu items I didn't like as much: - The Berry Hotcakes are also quite popular here, serving a generous portion of berries. The Hotcakes are very thick and filling however, and best for sharing among a group of 5-8 people (definitely not for one person). - The Pink Pasta was quite thick/creamy and small in portion size. I personally am not a huge fan of creamy pastas however so I may be biased here. - I also got to try the Garlic Fries as a side item, and found it to be the most mediocre item on the menu (among many exceptional items). Additional factors:- Location is a bit out of the way (need to taxi)- You pay the price. I went as a group of 3, ordering 3 mains, 1 side, and 2 coffees. The bill came out to $105 (and this was over lunch)!I definitely want to come back to try their other items. Overall a great ambiance with light wood, freshly roasted coffee, and friendly staff. Strongly recommend, if it wasn't for the price tag!

address: 38 South Buona Vista Rd Singapore 118164 Singapore
comment: Located after the windy road off S. Buona Vista (nearer to Pasir Panjang) is this hipster cafe. There will be a row of shophouses and it is next to the intersection of Lorong Sarhad.Came here on a Monday around 1.30pm for my cousin's birthday party. Since my mother and I were the last one to arrive, some dishes are laid on the long dining table and we could taste some of the leftovers.Tried the risotto. Since it has been out for awhile before I arrive, the taste was not too great. We also tried the hot chick (fried "popcorn" chicken). Pretty well done as it was served after we arrived. The homemade chilli on the side did pair well with the chicken bites. The chicken skin was crunchy and the meat itself was juicy when served.My aunt then decided to order Kimchi Fried Rice for both my mother and I. We did not wait for long for it. When it arrived, it came in a bigger portion than expected (serves up to 2 or 3 pax). The lighting at the longest table was not that great hence I had to snap a quick photo before tasting the dish.For this dish, I love the steak slices. I ordered medium well and it turned out chewy and juicy to my likings. The kimchi portion for this dish was small. Would prefer it to be slightly more. The steaks definitely overpowered the flavors in the dish. For the rice, it was well-fried. The color of the fried rice were constant throughout the dish and the flavors linger in the mouth. Definitely one of the recommended dish here.I managed to try the "famous and instagramable" Berry Ricotta hotcakes. The berries were sweet and well-spread around the hotcakes. But the hotcakes itself was a little dry for me. Service was not bad either. The staffs approached quickly when you raised your hand. Price wise, it would be better if it is slightly cheaper. Will be back to try out other dishes.

address: 38 South Buona Vista Rd Singapore 118164 Singapore
comment: Went on a Sunday at noon and thankfully got seated quite promptly. (There was a long line when we left at 1pm). Ambience was great - we were seated at the bar so we could watch the baristas in action. Service was also prompt. The quinoa salmon was well-executed, with the quinoa providing a satisfying crunch. The salmon was moist and flavorful. Portion's not very big though. Was hoping to order the squid ink pasta but it wasn't on the menu anymore. Ordered the uni tagliatelle and wasn't disappointed. The prawn was fresh and the pasta creamy with uni. Highly recommended. Ordered the berry hotcake due to the rave reviews I've seen on social media. It came extremely prettily plated, and there was a good assortment of berries. The cake itself though, was slightly too dry for my liking, though spots of cream in the cake was a nice tough. The cake itself wasn't too sweet, which was good, but I wouldn't come here just for this. It's a slightly pricey place for brunch. The above 3 dishes + a latte came up to $70+, though on the whole one of my preferred cafes in Singapore.

address: 38 South Buona Vista Rd Singapore 118164 Singapore
comment: This place is worth the trip down! Went on Sunday noon and there was a queue, but got a seat with my 3 friends after awhile. Quality in the food and friendly staff, felt that the food quality was almost restaurant standard, definitely exceed the usual cafe standards in Singapore!The pink pasta and kimchi fried rice was so goooooood, everyone ordered a different main and really liked all the dishes after we shared them. Highly recommended to try out this place.

address: 38 South Buona Vista Rd Singapore 118164 Singapore
comment: New-kid-on-the-block, Paddy Hills's location is not new to us. What used to be the familiar Lim Seng Lee Duck Rice shop has now become a hip, Instagram-able café. If you're an adventurous food-lover, you will love Paddy Hills for their creative Australian-Japanese International Fusion Food and specialty coffee. Try their Golden Man Tou with Truffle Fries for an appetizing bite or Hao Da De Ji for sharing if you're with a big group.A coffee bar occupies the centre space of the café where one can opt to sit at the bar to observe the skilful baristas at work. Psst, we spied the Slayer Espresso machine AKA the "Ferrari" of coffee machines.If you're looking for a spacious place with good Wi-Fi (it's the Neon Pink words on the wall outside!) and a soothing ambience to get some work done, drop by Paddy Hills on a weekday. We visited on a weekday and the crowd was gleefully minimal although we heard that it can get really crowded on weekends.Touted as a café in the day and a tapas bar at night, we will be sure to stop by in the evening for our next visit.

address: 38 South Buona Vista Rd Singapore 118164 Singapore
comment: Eclectic fusion finger food served while you lounge on vintage chairs.This very recently opened restaurant/drinks spot is located where the famous Lim Seng Lee Duck Rice Eating House once stood. The large windows, industrial-chic looking interior, differently textured walls of concrete, plywood and neon lighting already scream hipster before you enter. It's rather comfortable inside as you settle down and start looking at the menu. Some items are meant for sharing and the rest were noodle or yakitori dishes. I was very intrigued by the fusion dishes and proceeded to order the fried man tou sliders and toasted spicy rice cakes.Six fried man tou sliders arrived arranged on a large plate with two different sauces and a side of truffle fries. I was more impressed with the pork belly sliders than the lamb sliders, which I felt were too lean and dry. The korean rice cakes (Tteokbokki) arrived with a suitably crispy and slightly charred exterior with a spicy sauce mixed with a raw egg, salmon roe (ikura) and some pork slices. Although I enjoyed the juxtaposition of textures and flavors, the sauce was too salty for my liking.The coffee, however, is decently good. I saw the USD$21,000 Slayer(tm) machine sitting on the counter. I also think they get their beans from a local roaster. Earlier, I observed staff members at the bar fiddle with the Slayer(tm) espresso machine and attempt to coax it to deliver the right consistency of caffeine shot.Prices are much higher to compensate for not levying a service charge. I'm a little on the fence as the food is interesting but being a week old meant they still had a lot of kinks to iron out. Their wait staff were still rather new and confused on procedure, and the kitchen took a really long time (45 mins) to churn out the dishes before running out of food and closing early at 8:45pm. I saw a couple of angry (and hungry) customers exchanging words with the service staff. The repeated adjustment, tweaking and fiddling with the espresso machine also didn't give me much confidence.As I left, I'm reminded again of the good coffee as I saw the crate that the Slayer machine arrived in, displayed outside and used as a bench or table. Duck rice fans, you will have to head over to Little India. There's no duck on the menu here.

address: 38 South Buona Vista Rd Singapore 118164 Singapore
comment: Came in here a second time in 7 days as I had not the opportunity to try the coffee the last time. Was the second customer of the day and ordered the latte and items from the breakfast menu. Wow!! Love the coffee (99-1 blend). Chocolately and creamy. Love the full bodied layers despite the milk in the latte. Ordered the small breakfast and berry ricotta hotcake. Great stuff again!! Small breakfast was polenta and a runny egg on toast, with the morning-welcome fragance of mushrooms and truffle. Hotcake was fantastic despite the 30-minute wait - great on the palatte and the eyes. Great for breakfast. The food quantity is actually good enuf for 2 persons to share so order accordingly. What a difference from my last brunch visit. Niceee

address: 38 South Buona Vista Rd Singapore 118164 Singapore
comment: Totally worth the trip out for a Saturday brunch.Cool and chill cafe with an interesting menu and sizable portions. I ordered the kimchi fried rice and totally devoured it in a few bites. The fried rice is prepared in such a way that it doesn't feel like you are eating typical Chinese fried rice, it feels like actual quality in every bite. It comes with some steak slices and an egg that you mix to add a bit more flavor. Totally recommend getting this plate.I also ordered the cauliflower fritters (didn't expect it to be such a large portion) and the Paradise Shake(?) (the one with coconut and torched pineapple). So so so good, the shake didn't even feel heavy.My girlfriend ordered the berry ricotta pancakes which were also really good.Highly recommend checking this place out. Service is excellent with a happy and smiling young bunch of staff. Will be coming back!

address: 38 South Buona Vista Rd Singapore 118164 Singapore
comment: Been here twice already and both times there were more hits than misses for all the dishes ordered. Service staff were friendly, polite and prompt. Food quality is better than most cafes out there, almost restaurant standard. Coffee is decent and they offer brew coffee too which is great! Only downside is that location-wise it's not as convenient but definitely worth a trip if you're nearby the area! Oh and I've never had to wait for a table because I went slightly after peak hours about 1.30pm.

address: 38 South Buona Vista Rd Singapore 118164 Singapore
comment: Pretty solid fare at a steep price. Pink pasta with scallop (singular) and prawn (also singular) was tasty but I would've appreciated more seafood for a $30 dish! The kimchi fried rice was also quite scrumptious and came with a good portion of medium rare steak, alas the steak was of middling quality. The real winner here were actually the cocktails (white sangria to be specific). At $18 a piece they aren't cheap but if you want to splurge it's worth it! It feels like you're paying for the vibe, which is fair given the dearth of hip places like this in Singapore, but I froze my butt off with the AC cranked up and they couldn't move us because of a lack of available tables.

address: 38 South Buona Vista Rd Singapore 118164 Singapore
comment: The pasta was really good! The mocha took the cake ;) yummy ! Though as I went in the evening they were out of all their specialities :( I would check with them and then go

address: 38 South Buona Vista Rd Singapore 118164 Singapore
comment: Great brunch with frens. Ordered mutton meatball, big breakfast and berries ricotta pancake. For drinks, we had 2 ounce white coffee and yuzu drink. Nice ambience and great food!

address: 38 South Buona Vista Rd Singapore 118164 Singapore
comment: Paddy Hills is a must-go for brunch. The Green Scramble & Bacon - house cured bacon chop, walnut pesto crushed potatoes & mustard dressing - is certainly worth the $23. Service is good too.

address: 38 South Buona Vista Rd Singapore 118164 Singapore
comment: Food-wise, it was a hit-and-miss averaging on decent, and occasionally bordering on so-so. Methinks Paddy Hills would make a pretty worthwhile option if you're in the area, but I don't think the food was excellent enough to warrant travelling from afar.The bistro is run by a lean workforce, but, for a place that doesn't have any service charge, service was fantastic - smiley and efficient. Another perk, no GST either! That said, my grouse was mainly regarding the menu, it tended towards unnecessary and wasted pretense. If a menu requires Dr Google's assistance to make an informed decision, that's far too much posturing. I mean, how many regular people know what bagna cauda is? Or even how to pronounce it?! Also, a girlfriend took issue with the mispresentation on the menu. What was named 'Hash Hash' with a description of "sauteed beef, mushroom, chorizo, doughstick and sous vide egg" turned out to be a beef bak kut teh. Calling a dish "hash", she said, and I quite agree, implies that the whole jin-gang is sauteed, as you would a breakfast hash. A soupy bak kut teh IS NOT a hash. Strip away the pretense, I think, and re-direct the effort to the food. That's what draws in the crowds anyway.We had:1) Berry Ricotta Hotcake ($23) adorned with blueberry sugar, pinenuts, raspberries, strawberries, blueberries, yuzu gel, and maple syrup: Very pretty, and it tasted as good as it looked. Thick, dense, but fluffy, these were the best pancakes I've had for as long as I can remember.2) Quesadillas ($20) stuffed with pulled duck and pickles, served with charred baby capsicum and sweet corn, and sided by a garlic aioli and guacamole: The quesadillas, in addition to being laced with parsley, were mediocre. My parsley-loving friend, who had this, said to give this a hard pass.3) Hash Hash ($24): Misleading description aside, this was a reasonably commendable and very comforting bowl of beef bak kut teh. Meltingly soft and wonderfully fatty, the luscious hunks of meat could have passed off as pork if I hadn't been informed otherwise. I particularly liked the western twist of the sous vide egg, arugula leaves, and chickpeas.4) Kimchi Fried Rice ($20): much touted, but turned out middling, even with the perfectly wobbly sous vide egg, and medium-well tender steak. I've had betterPictures are at thehungrybunnie.blogspot…

address: 321 Alexandra Rd #01-02, Alexandra Central Singapore 159971 Singapore
comment: Prata is thick and crispy. But the service was poor. I didn't get my food and had to ask for it as they had seemed to lose my order.

address: 321 Alexandra Rd #01-02, Alexandra Central Singapore 159971 Singapore
comment: Master Prata I'm not usually upset about prices but I cannot stand their attitude and the dirty tables. So then I'm not happy with the small piece of fish for $6+ that was not even hot.Dirty tables (every single one) so had no choice but to select one.Asked staff to clean and he put his hand up asking me to wait and refused to come out to clean the table. So I had to clean the table myself!Won't ever go again!

address: 321 Alexandra Rd #01-02, Alexandra Central Singapore 159971 Singapore
comment: AVOID AT ALL COSTS. WORST SERVICE EVER. The chef rudely took back my plate of prata to check if its the correct order then forcefully threw it back on the counter. VERY RUDE. Food is also extremely overpriced and sub par. The dishonest cashier also tried to add items on my order that I didn't requested for.

address: 26 Sentosa Gateway #01-292, Festive Walk Resorts World Sentosa Singapore 098138 Singapore
comment: Back in 2011 when I was in Singapore, I used to go here every week from march - july. So I'm pretty much a regular here. Service is great, location is perfect - you can take a nice stroll after your dinner. I love how they offer signature dishes from the four famous restaurants in Singapore. I always get their cereal prawns, tofu with spinach, black pepper beef, black pepper crab and chilli crab with fried man tous. I recently went back to Singapore for a short trip and was disappointed to find out that they removed their chrysanthemum ribs. BRING IT BACK. It was so good.

address: 26 Sentosa Gateway #01-292, Festive Walk Resorts World Sentosa Singapore 098138 Singapore
comment: Food was so-so. Typical seafood restaurant menu with below average taste. If there was anything remarkable with my dining experience here - it was how oblivious staff was to the needs of diners. Service was non-existent and staff had to be told exactly what diners needed (e.g. utensils, bib and gloves for the crab, water, etc). It took 20 minutes for us to get a bowl of rice. If you are coming to Singapore for chili crab - getting here will not be a great idea. I give this place three spoons out of ten.

address: 26 Sentosa Gateway #01-292, Festive Walk Resorts World Sentosa Singapore 098138 Singapore
comment: Maybe it is the location, out in Sentosa, or there is a labor crunch. In any case, the service was bad to non-existent when we were there on a Friday night. My uncle booked a private room with 2 tables for a family dinner. There was a minimum spend required for a private room ($500 per table, so $1000 for 2 tables). After the staff took our orders, the service went downhill. We ordered fried rice and fried noodles first while waiting for the others as there were kids and we wanted to settle their rumbling stomachs first. It still took about 45 minutes for the fried rice to be served. And my cousin had to go find the ready dishes and it basically became a self service dinner. For most of the dishes, my cousin went out of the room and brought in the food, with the pegs and papers still attached to the plates. We had to repeat our request for warm water 3 to 5 times before it was served. I actually went out to help myself but was told by the server to wait and they would bring it in. But zilch. The service got a bit better towards the end (close to 9pm or after 9pm) as someone actually brought in the dishes. So maybe there was just not enough service staff to handle the dinner rush of 7pm - 9pm and so food was left cooling in the holding area. The food quality was ok, as what you would get in any of the Jumbo (or the others) outlets. The problem was with the lack of service. We paid at least $1000++ for a private room. You would think the service would be slightly better with at least a dedicated staff to the room. It is just appalling. Imagine if this is a business dinner and this happened. The private rooms are on the 2nd level and I am not sure if there are any elevators for those who have difficulties in climbing stairs. So 2 stars for this place even if the food is good.

address: 26 Sentosa Gateway #01-292, Festive Walk Resorts World Sentosa Singapore 098138 Singapore
comment: The most delicious food we ever had! Best sea food! Try chili crab! Just wow!!!Service is good too! Love this place

address: 26 Sentosa Gateway #01-292, Festive Walk Resorts World Sentosa Singapore 098138 Singapore
comment: inside the resort world area. singapore chili crab 900g 88 with perfect sauce and mantou.  pricey but nice.  good coffee ribs too

address: 26 Sentosa Gateway #01-292, Festive Walk Resorts World Sentosa Singapore 098138 Singapore
comment: Out in Sentosa, so maybe not too many people know about it. Came here because my cousin had a coupon but the place was also quite delicious. The restaurant is a hybrid of 5 chefs from reputable restaurants that highlight each respective signature dishes.FRIED SMALL FISH: more of an appetizer than anything else.CHILLI CRAB: absolutely delicious. Does have a kick to it but still not too spicy that you don't want to eat it. The sauce is also perfect for dipping that perfectly warm and soft STEAMED BUNS.BLACK PEPPER CRAB: way too much pepper for my own taste. So much that I couldn't eat too much of it because I also ended up inhaling the black pepper and that was painful.FRIED PRAWNS WITH CEREAL: Prawns are sautéed with a special blend of oat cereal, curry leaves and fiery chilli padi. Also one of my favorites mainly because of the sweet oat cereal. DEEP FRIED SCALLOP WRAPPED IN YAM RING: Fresh whole scallop, embedded in soft yam paste, deep fried and served with traditional sweet "Ngoh Hiang' sauce. This one was also a WINNER. The yam was soft and the ring was very crispy. The scallop also tasted very fresh.SERVICE: the service was ok. It could have been a lot better considering the atmosphere of the restaurant and the fact that there were not many customers. They took a while to take our orders and would forget to bring out certain dishes until we mentioned it to them.ENVIRONMENT: rather than nice ambiance since it's in the Sentosa area. There are multiple stories so just remember where you party is if you come separately. Inside the restaurant is bright with white seat covers. It feels fancy but not to the point you know you're breaking the bank (even though you are).Overall, I'm glad my cousin introduced us to this place. However, fortunately we had a couple otherwise it would have costed us a fortune. Though none the less a lot of things in Singapore are expensive. Despite the cost, I would still come back every now and then to eat some of this delicious food!

address: 26 Sentosa Gateway #01-292, Festive Walk Resorts World Sentosa Singapore 098138 Singapore
comment: The chili crab was excellent.   Be prepared to spend at least $300 for 4 people, but well worth it.   Order some extra buns to soak up all the sauce from the crab!!!!

address: 26 Sentosa Gateway #01-292, Festive Walk Resorts World Sentosa Singapore 098138 Singapore
comment: Had their three-course meal offered by Groupon at $88 which served Award Winning Chilli Crab, Herbal Drunken Prawn (believe it was my favorite tiger prawn), and Steamed Red Snapper (steamed fish). Initially, I thought that the food won't be great as me being a cheapskate purchasing a $88 food voucher worth $158. But to my surprise...... I highly recommend this place. Great place to hang out with friends and family. After your meal, try taking a 10-min walk by the sea to Vivo City, it's good for digestion. One negative comment though. I went there on a Wednesday's evening and they seem to be short of staff.

address: Lock Road Bukit Merah, Singapore Singapore
comment: I've met The Travelling C.O.W. (Chef On Wheels) on several occasions, they seem to like popping up at the more artsy events that I attend - think Singapore Night Festival, Art After Dark @ Gillman Barracks etc. While I may have brushed past them at other events, it was finally at Gillman that I decided to take the plunge into my first affair with a food truck. I am wildly fascinated with food trucks and wish there were more of such in Singapore - unfortunately I guess there are permit and license issues aplenty and thus, we do not get to have food zooming around in trucks and straight to our (actually, mostly my) tummy! But then again, we have food at every MRT station, I guess food trucks wouldn't go well after the initial novel period for Singaporeans - we're an unfaithful bunch when it comes to food, cause there's too many things in Singapore to fall in love with already. My first brush with C.O.W. was a hit and a miss - mostly a hit though, but unfortunately Cupid didn't strike while the iron was hot as my Truffle Mac & Cheese Balls came half cold. I was yearning to bite down into an oozy, warm ball of yellow, cheesy goodness because the cup in my hand that held these scared balls was warm, hot even, to touch. But alas, my first bite was of cold, stale batter and a slight whiff of truffle on cold, stuck together pasta. The truffle monster in me roared as I was expecting a little more - its craving was not satisfied. The lady who handed my eager, excited being the food ask 'So how is it?' and in classic polite Singaporean-style, I told her it was yummy with a twinkle in my eyes. I had taken a bite and didn't want to send the food back to the kitchen. It was a rough night for them as the queues for food were long and I didn't want to be a mean person holding the line up. I had another two more balls of the same quality, and my last few balls at the bottom of the cup were slightly warmer, but still had the same stuck together, not really truffle-oil infused disappointment.The partner-in-crime (who had begrudgingly trudged his way to this godforsaken Gillman Barracks because he doesn't understand art but, #boyfduties) was rewarded for his valiant effort to pretend to understand all the abstract notions of art with an extremely yummy tasting Chilli Crab Pasta. At first look, there's nothing to fall in love with, it was a mess of sauce splayed over pasta - but the moment you get a whiff of it ... you see a bit of Singaporean heaven. I stole about 1/4 of the pasta that was supposed to be his dinner because it was so so yummy! The chilli crab sauce while not a vicious as the actual dish was seasoned and tasted perfectly like the real thing - put that with pasta, and I'm quite sold. Anyone who can cook half decent pasta in a truck deserves a pat on the back - and the sauce totally just makes you forget that the pasta ain't al dente. Overall, I came out of the experience a bit wary about loving it too much because of the Truffle Mac & Cheese Balls, but if their usual other dishes (like the Ramen Burger) that I want to try are more towards Chilli Crab Pasta standards, I think I'll become a loyal (event) patron of the Travelling C.O.W.

address: Lock Road Bukit Merah, Singapore Singapore
comment: If it's not the food craze that drove New Yorkers insane, and potentially Singaporeans. The Travelling C.O.W has come up with their version of the Ramen Burger, which consists of two golden crisp ramen patties and filled with some succulent meats, paired with a secret dressing. The Bulgogi Beef burger is a crowd pleaser, a mild sweet juicy burger. I liked the Spicy BBQ Chicken, which is more savory than spicy. The sauce provided the right amount of flavors for the otherwise bland noodle patty. More could be done to the consistency of the fried noodles, but when golden brown, it goes great with the saucy gravy. Skip the Mushroom Fricasse, instant mushroom noodles would have tasted better. Burgers are going for about $9. Be ready for a mess when eating the burger.

We ordered set D $398++ (subject to 10% service charge and 7% GST) for 9 to 10 pax.Menu-Shanghai Xiao Long Bao-Soft shell crab garden green salad (very nice)-Sze Chuan source with peppers prawn and cuttle fish-Braised shredded dried scallop soup with Four Treasures-Cod Fish with oat, golden mushroom and black fungus in fish broth-Roasted chicken with almond and garlic crisps-Stir fried hong Kong vegetables-steam rice with chicken feet, spare ribs or minced pork with salted fish in lotus leaf-oat, pumpkin ball with fungus and sweet scented osmanthus jellyAll the dishes are nice except the dessert. The pumpkin ball is hard to bite.

If you love dim sum and Chinese food but can't stand the queues at restaurants like Din Tai Fung and Tim ho wan, this is an excellent alternative. Black Society (previously called Bosses Restaurant) is located in Vivocity and offers good food at reasonable prices. Per other yelpers suggestions, I got to try some of their items such as: Shumai, Char su bun, egg custard bun, short ribs, and prawn congee. All were very tasty but the Shumai and Congee were most memorable to me. I would definitely come back here for reasonable priced Chinese food in a nice ambiance

Besides the really cool name and mysterious/dark décor, the Dim Sum here is delicious and made with good quality ingredients. The staff are trained to provide prompt service and old and young alike are very pro-active.Our verdict:- Steamed village radish cake: this is the steam version of the fried carrot cake. It's a new dish on their Spring menu and I must say, it offers a different take on the traditional dim sum type of carrot cake. It's hard to describe it holistically but the picture says it all. Try this but note that the portion is quite huge if you're in a group of 2 so it may be best to cut down on other filling carbs if you wanna order this.- Prawn beancurd roll: the smell of this simply makes my mouth water. The portion is kinda small (3 pcs) for $7 but the taste is heavenly. The skin is fried to perfection and complements well with the inner fillings. This is my must-order dish on every visit.- Century egg and pork porridge: I never fail to order this dish every time I have dim sum but somehow this dish is a-ok; not too good not too bad. There are a few measly pieces of pork and century egg pieces but the texture of the porridge is faultless. Suggest to skip this dish if you have other interesting items to order on the menu.- Pan-fried juicy meat buns (3 pcs): another new item on the Spring menu and I gave up my order of Xiao Long Bao just because of the word 'juicy' and I thought it would be interesting to see how something juicy could be pan-fried! However, I was disappointed as it was anything but juicy. It's my expectations failing me! Other then it being not juicy as I expected, the buns were of a good size and the meat filling was quite flavourful. Why isn't it juicy?- Hot and Sour Dumplings (4 pcs): another dish that I absolutely love; the hotness and sourness is just right! A warning though, it may be a bit too spicy for those who are unable to take spicy food.I am already planning to return within the next two weeks and it's one of the places I would recommend to friends if they are craving for some Dim Sum within the Harbourfront area.

They changed name from bosses to Black Society, I've been here so many times, the food is still the same good , I like them, staffs are still very good at service . Same thing you have to know is that the snacks and towels are chargeable ! If you don't want the snacks and you have your own towel, you have to tell the cashier that you are not using them !

Went there for brunch. Food was good, but the service SUCKS!First of all, I don't like how they sneak stuff onto the table that they'll charge you for it without telling you. They gave us a small plate of fried fish skin before the food comes. Normally, you wouldn't think they charge for it in the US. Like how restaurants give you bread before your food comes out. But here, they charge you $4 for that stupid plate of fish skin! What a ripoff! The guy who was like a manager had a really bad attitude. This place sucks!

It's surprising that Singapore with such a deep Chinese community/influence doesn't have more high-end/high-quality Dim Sum places. It's a good thing Tim Ho Wan has come to town and opened up a dozen or more stores to alleviate this reality. Enter Black Society Restaurant, formerly called Bosses Restaurant. This restaurant serves the high-quality dim sum that Hong Kong is so well known for. No none of that late night Dim Sum that we so often see in Geylang that are touted / raved by locals. I mean very very high quality Dim Sum.I tried 5 dim sum dishes, which were all downright amazing.(i) Prosperity Bag Shumai (Crowd favourite) - Your regular shumai that we all know and love, but with a lot more  pizzas(ii) Traditional Char Siu Bun - Your regular Char Siu Bun, but this was by far the best one I've tried in Singapore -- far tastier than one you would normally taste at street vendors or Uncle Dim Sum establishments(iii) Snow Mountain Black Pepper Beef Bun (Crowd Favourite) - In my opinion, very similiar to the Char Siu Bun with a nice white powdery touch. (iv) Prawn and Beancurd Skin Rice Roll ( Crowd Favourite) - Very crunchy and tasty. A must have to balance out any Dim Sum selection(v) Basket Steam Spare Ribs (Crowd Favourite) - Wow, wow, wow. I've never had spare ribs like that. The spare ribs had a little bit of kick, especially if you happen to bite into the chili In my opinion, five-stars because high-quality Dim Sum is such a rare find in Singapore. It's too bad it is locate all the way in VivoCity.

If you're looking for an up-scale Din Tai Fung, this is the place to go!We went for dimsum during a weekday brunch around 11am. It was pretty empty then but spots quickly filled in by 11:45am.  The dimsum looked like regular dimsum, but we could tell the ingredients used were more fresh than the regular dimsum places (which explains the price of the items). The presentation of the vegetable dish (spinach sautéed with garlic) though was nicely placed (we were more amused by this since we were not expecting sauteed spinach to be a fancy-looking veggie dish). The service was a bit slow and it was hard to get the waiters' attention. Overall, this restaurant was a 3.5/5.

I made a reservation online and the staff called me within 5 mins to confirm my reservation, that was really impressive.Went there and it was a different story. The waitress taking my order was rather condescending, it could be how we are dressed. Four adults and two children, all wearing tee shirt and shorts. Asked her to intro food after ordering a porridge, a fried rice, and two noodles. She said these should be enough for us. I then ordered the liu sha bao and the Xiao long bao as sides. The orders took a while to arrive and after eating everything, the fried rice never showed. Asked 2 waiters and still nothing, just told us to wait. So went to the lady at the counter and she just took my receipts and walked away. Few mins later she came back and from a distance away said very loudly that they are frying now. I responded just as loudly to cancel the order as the wait was too ridiculous. So food wise, someone said the prawn porridge is good, I disagree. It's very watery although the prawns are very fresh. The stir fry udon is cooked with vinegar, so taste like vinegar. The other Chinese noodles is cooked with sweet sauce, slightly better but taste sweet. (Didn't even bother to remember the names)The Xiao long bao and the liu sha bao is nice though. Anyway, I won't go there again. Bad service and expensive. Forget it.

Came here to have babies showers for three of my church mates on a Saturday evening around 4pm (high tea promotion - last order at 5pm) with a few Yelpers.Inside the restaurant, most of the interior design consist of the color black. It did stood out to me. Thanks to Nayoung (one of the organizers for the babies showers), who made the reservation, we were able to sit in a big round table for 11 of us who were present that day. We were given the seats that has panoramic view of Sentosa. The sun rays directed to us and one of the attentive staffs asked me whether I would like to lower the blinds down as I was the first to arrive.After being ushered to the table, I headed to the restroom, located at the back of the restaurant. It was not as bright as I would like it to be and the toilets are pretty narrow and not much space to put our belongings. The one thing that fascinated me was not the mirrors towards the toilet but the sink. It was electronically sensored so you will have to use one hand to wave on the sensor while the water trickled down like waterfall. Service wise it was pretty inconsistent. Sometimes it might take awhile before the staffs come over to check on your needs.Food wise, one of my friends ordered.1) Har Gau (prawn dumpling) - was not warm enough. 2) Sweet corn pancake - did not taste it 3) Panfried radish cake with XO sauce - was alright 4) Prawn toast - highly recommended. The batter they use to get the dish made it crunchy and addictive 5) Crispy Mango Prawn Salad Roll with wasabi mayo - unfortunately I was not a fan of it even though it was Chinese fritters with prawn inside.6) Radish pancake - pretty good. It had quite a number of ingredients and made the dish to be collectively crunchy7) Prawn and beancurd skin rice roll - pretty interesting fusion dish. The beancurd skin was like those that are available for sushi. And flavor definitely popped out upon munching8) Signature custard lava bun - did not try it as it is a common dish at most restaurants that offer dim sum. (Took pretty long time before being served. Had to remind the staffs at least twice)Overall, food was alright.Prices wise it was considered reasonable especially located in one of the tourist must-go spots. Do check with the staff on the portion of the dishes.We were also served with the deep-fried fish skins and sesame with probably honey coated walnuts (if I didn't remember wrongly). Will probably try out their volcano black pepper bun and their signature custard buns during my next trip here.Thing to take note of that are chargeable here: wet napkins and glasses of water. And do check whether they discounted the prices of the dishes for the high-tea promotion (Monday to Saturday: 2.30pm to 5.30pm).

The mall directory identified this restaurant as Black Society, loosely translated to Chinese mafia in Chinese. Here, traditional Singaporean Cantonese dishes are served in a hip ambience, albeit the traditional display of aquariums of live fish and shell fish visible as we entered the establishment. The 9 of us had the dinner set menu D which IMO is priced very reasonably. We were fortunate the place wasn't quite 50% filled on a Wednesday evening so we were served very quickly. Most of the dishes were portioned and served individually to us. We appreciated we didn't have to carve from an entire fish complete with its head and tail which can turn some off. Every item in the set menu was well put together and very tasty, there wasn't anything anyone did not like.

In line with the restaurant's Chinese name which literally means "black society", the color scheme of the place is black. The setting was sleek and I expected the prices to be higher than other overcrowded chain Chinese restaurants but was pleasantly surprised by the reasonable prices. My friend had typical dim sum items like char siew bun and har gow. The dim sum baskets were unique. I ordered abalone prawn congee which is one of the best congee I have ever eaten. Most restaurants use the same plain congee as the base and just add ingredients as per the order, such that prawn congee is just plain congee+prawns but the one I had here tasted like the congee was cooked with the prawns long enough to absorb the essence. Highly recommended!

Bosses Restaurant, a good Chinese dining place, good ambiance, good service and nice toilets! Firstly, I love their dim sum there, and the last time I was there for their dim sum tea special, my friends and I couldn't stop ordering. It was that good. The service is commendable and no, we didn't feel like bosses nor mafias, but we were happy customers. I didn't like their custard buns, even though it's their signature dish. And you have to check out their toilets. No, it's not a maze nor you are in Alice's wonderland. I shall not spoil the fun. Have a look yourself, boss!

If you fancy something different from the usual Chinese dishes you get at those Chinese restaurants, Bosses is the place you may want to give a try. The restaurant is furnished in black, and possibly had its name inspired by the mafia in Hong Kong, commonly known as Hak Se Wui (literally translates to Black Society). You will not only find Cantonese items on the menu, you will also find some Shanghainese food items. In particular, the dim sum items are hot favorites as what is served at Bosses is probably more exquisite than what you commonly get outside. I highly recommend you to try the signature flowy custard buns, as well as the seafood congee (forgot the exact name of the dish). The ingredients used are fresh, and definitely very very tasty!What's more, it's got a pretty nice and relaxed atmosphere, contrary to its name. The staff are nice and attentive too, which gives the overall experience an A! The only downside is the cost. The things are slightly pricey, so be prepared to pay a little more.Worth it or not? Well, you can be the boss.

Looking for a nice place with yummy dim sum for afternoon high tea, this is the place to go. Their high tea ala carte orders are at  30% discount on monday  to saturday from 2:30pm to 5:30pm.  Oh yes. The must have here is their Liu Sa Bao (Custard Buns). Die die must try!  My friends and I love it so much that the waitress got a big shocked when we order 5 servings of it for a table of 8  (15pcs)

If you are a frequent shopper in Vivocity, you will tend to notice that there is this particular restaurant that is fully furnished in black colour. The shop name is called . Once you enter, you will feel how unique the decoration is. Their theme is black in colour. It gives me a very classy and secretive kind of feeling.I have heard many excellent reviews on their famous custard buns. Highly recommended by many of my colleagues. Hence, the first dish to start with will definitely be that. Once the custard buns arrive, I'm really excited like a little kid. Couldn't wait for the rush of custard that is going to flow out. It really did not disappoint me at all. Best custard buns I have ever tasted. Hands down!Next dish I would highly recommend is their signature seafood congee with abalone and prawns. The prawns are really fresh. You can really taste the sweetness and freshness of the seafood in the porridge. Plus, they include ikan bilis to the porridge, which add on saltiness to the porridge. Perfect!

For full reviews and photos, visit my blog!I know that the famous Michelin Star dim sum Tim Ho Wan has arrived in town. But if you are unwilling to beat that looooooooooooong queue at Plaza Singapure, may i suggest another comfortable alternative- Bosses at Vivocity.While it may not be 1 star quality, prices are affordable, location is convenient, ambience isn't too shady and the dim sum are generally quite consistent. I was first introduced to it by a girlfriend because the 30% discount at tea time seemed quite appealing to us. Available from Mon to Sat from  2.30pm to 5.30pm, this is a pretty good deal for what is usually priced at $4-6 per box of little bites. And we were not disappointed. I've eaten here a couple of times following that first visit and it satisfies this hungry tummy.    Appetizer of fried fish skin. I know it looks eeeky and all and i have always avoided this dish until my recent trip to Bosses. The auntie server convinced me that it's great with the sweet chili and well.. it didn't turn out as bad as i've imagined. It's just like keropok aka fish crackers. One of my usual orders at Bosses is their Salted Egg Yolk Custard Bun or Liu Sha Bao. The skin of the steamed bun is soft and fluffy and the golden sauce inside was of the right level of saltiness and viscosity. There was also a light coconut perfume that i can never seem to place but anything goes as long as it's tasty. This is one of the better ones around in Singapore.Fat juicy and flavorful prawns in my Har Gow. I would like the prawns to be a little bouncier but i wouldn't say that the mix is too powdery. My twin's seafood/prawn craving was satisfied. The meat dumplings, Siew Mai, was also topped with pretty butterflied prawns. I love how the meat wasn't too minced up that they lose their chewiness. Very substantial unlike the regular steamed siew mais in lesser establishments. The meat was also well marinated and fragrant. If you happen to be shopping in Vivocity, Bosses is a good option for a late lunch or tea.

I visited Bosses with family friends who frequent this restaurant. With their stamp of approval, I knew the food would be of reasonable quality and I was not disappointed. It isn't a traditional Chinese restaurant by any means and its decor informs you of just that when you walk in. The restaurant is washed in dark sleek tones, which is an uncommon yet modern choice.The wait staff are attentive and they check on your tea pot quite frequently, which is a sign of good service. We had a good view of the sea and further afield, Resorts World Sentosa and Universal Studios. If you are here for dinner, you might catch the nightly fireworks display, which is a bonus.Some highlights of our dinner were the aromatic crispy duck and the drunken prawns. These are must-tries not only for the flavor and texture but also for their presentation. I would return again, and this time for the dim sum.

Located at Vivocity level 2, this restaurant is quite difficult to find as it does not have a distinctive sign or logo at their door step. This Chinese restaurant gives a very mysterious feeling but once you step inside , you will feel that the deco and design is very modern and classy. Personally I like the lightings, giving it an extra point to the ambience.They are famous for their salted custard bun, eat it immediately when served! But beware of the salted custard that ooze out from the bun, it is really hot. I am sure you will ask for more , one is just not enough to satisfy. Another dish I would recommend is their abalone porridge. The porridge is cooked with rich abalone taste, you will find that they do not scrimp on the ingredients.Price might be on a high side but it is definitely a good place to hold celebration for family occasions or for the elderly as their cuisine is oriental.

Their liu sha bao is my favorite . In my option , it is best liu sha bao in Singapore . Their dim sum has very good quality, outperform than a lot of other Chinese restaurant . Their dish has very good presentation, balance taste , not oily. A bit expensive relatively . Better to go in the afternoon to enjoy their dim sum
If you're looking for contemporary chinese cuisine, this is the place to check it out. A little pricier but the food is good, ambience is great (nice view of the water) and lightning fast service

Surprisingly delicious take on local cuisine with a fun twist! The raman pizza and green curry mussels appetizer were my favorites. My husband loved the salted egg calamari. This is a place where the chefs really care about their creations. We can't wait to go back and try other tapas and I hear they make a great brunch, too!

address: 8 Sentosa Gateway Level 1, The Forum Southern Islands 098269 Singapore
comment: First off, lets just give this place a Michelin star already!!! Chef Benjamin Halat is one of the best chefs I've had the privilege of dining with. The 8 course meal he prepared for my wife and I was divine! The theme of the meal was fall in Germany and it was packed with renditions of traditional and childhood foods he had growing up. the first course was serve in the wine cellar because it was warm and the cellar was a bit nippy. So many considerations went into this meal. I can't begin to articulate with any decency the quality and craftsmanship of this meal. Curate is a small space with not too many tables so here is enough room to breath and enough space for the servers and chef to come out and speak without being drowned out by noise. The décor was filled with copper and light and was extremely welcoming. All of the alcohol pairings were spot on and the service staff were excellent. This was the first time I've ever eaten a course with tweezers! It was weird and it was fun. One of those experiences I will never forget. I'd recommend this restaurant to anyone looking for high end, well articulated cuisine.Not so humbly submitted,Michael C.

address: 8 Sentosa Gateway Level 1, The Forum Southern Islands 098269 Singapore
comment: in this case, to bring you michelin starred restaurants, from all over the world, so you don't have to leave SG!partially hidden behind planted shrubs, in a weak attempt to avoid catching the sharp radar eyes of pokemon trainers, is an oasis, painstakingly put together to showcase the biggest names in the culinary theatre, with a new name popping up every two months or so.just completed is series 3, the one i had the privilege of indulging in, featuring star-studded Chef Esben Holmboe Bang of Norwegian restaurant Maaemo.some pre-dinner pokemon hunting at rws, worked up our thirst and appetite but it was the sg climate friendly, tranquil setting, away from the humidity and heat that pleased the senses the most upon arrival!the next big thing was being greeted by esben and his warm, firm, reassuring handshake!i think we are in good hands?next, the kitchen and the service teams seamlessly harmonized to deliver an exalting experience.the wine pairing was sublime and seemingly bottomless.they were almost apologetic when our wine glasses were dry, before the next course could arrive, and generously offered top ups!indeed it was through no fault of theirs, the fault was in the wines, too good to sip and i barbarically gulped them down!this must be the only wine pairing dinner that i have actually emptied, every glass they served me!i don't think i can fault any of them exquisite dishes, you norwegians are so lucky to have esben, and you know it.the five star experience was cemented by the capturing of the oh so cute pokemon chansey, right outside their main entrance.yes, you can spin pokestops and catch pokemons throughout your entire meal here, no wonder time just flew by!am just a tad sad the pokemon gym was just a little beyond reach.otherwise, i am looking forward to returning in november for series 4, when ramon freixa flaunts his artistry.

E-Sarn is hands down the best Thai place myself and my family have ever gone to. Our Thai friends introduced us 6 years ago (which just proves how authentic and good it MUST be!) and we've been going regularly ever since. We bring all our guests and visitors, and they all agree on how wonderful E-Sarn is!The service is wonderful and friendly, and extremely fast! As soon as we order, it's almost at our table instantaneously.Our favourite dishes are the sun-dried pork, clear tom yam seafood soup, fish cakes, cha om (thai vegetable omelette) as well as the mango salad, and have become our regulars when we pay our visits. We've never found another Thai restaurant in Singapore that tops E-Sarn, and honestly, that's fine, as we love E-Sarn and would not trade it for anything!

This restaurant is managed by a team of Thai staffs so the food is expected to be good.My most recent trip was on Monday with my husband and a friend of mine. We initially ordered the green curry, grilled pork salad and stir fried kang kong. However, after seeing how tiny the portions were, my husband quickly added another order of basil minced pork.Green curry looked more yellow than green but it tasted pretty good. Kang kong was ok. It was fresh with the spicy kick. Grilled pork salad: I think the taste is altered to cater to the numerous expats living in the area. Typical Thai salads, or "yum", usually have strong sour and spicy taste. However the dish is rather mild (and also lacks the aromatic crushed rice bits).Minced pork and basil: I'm utterly disappointed with this dish. It doesn't look anything like a basil minced pork. It's more like the chef accidentally threw in an entire bottle of Chilli paste. Ironically, the dish doesn't come with much basil. I highly recommend that they change the name of this dish to stir fried minced pork with Chilli paste. The 4 items, 2 Thai ice teas, and 3 rice portions cost us 75 dollar. I don't remember it being so costly but I guess that's because it's been quite some time since I last came here. That said, it will be another long while before I come back here again. It's too painful to part with my money knowing that there are better and cheaper places to visit.

Good place for Thai food. Nice restaurant setting and location if you want to get away from crowded shopping malls. Located just across the road from pasir Panjang mrt station. Two girlfriends and I shared a large pad thai, minced chicken with chili and omelette with minced pork. The pad thai has the right amount of gravy and taste. The minced chicken came in a decent portion and was not too spicy. The star was the omelette which was super crispy and addictive. My friend also enjoyed the coconut drink. It's a pity that the mango desserts were not available during our visit.
Love e-sarn, delivers every time. (And I come here every other week)Little pricy but worth it!

Good food though inconsistent of late. Very poor value at their much increased prices. Tiny portions - large salad is enough for a nibble for 2. And service remains poor. Pity this erstwhile gem is slipping fast.

I really like this restaurant. It has been my go to place for Thai restaurant.I like all the food that we ordered. The grilled pork is very tasty, the fried fish with green chili is crunchy. The gai lan is good. The green curry & tom yum are good as well. Food is overall very satisfying. Minus one star for being so far down south and a little on the pricey end for Thai food. For the price I paid for 5 dishes ($150), you may fly a return flight on budget airline when it is on sale to BKK. Hahaha It is also a place that is frequented by many expats. I didn't know Pasir Panjang is quite popular with the expats.

Simply the best Thai food in Singapore!! I like this place so much I eat there 1-2 a week. I took several friends and colleagues to E-Sarn and they all loved it too! Also the staff are great and the prices are very reasonable.

The food was absolutely deli opus and the mostly Thai was friendly and helpful and they picked out some Singapore twang in their accent as well which was pleasing.Had the fish cake, mango salad, green curry and glass noodle with prawns. All dishes were fantastic.
Great set lunches. Worth your money, but there may be a queue.The cooks are all Thai, so it is really authentic Thai food. i love the olive fried rice.:)

Try their herb salad and Thai vegetable omelette cha om! You don't get them in most other Thai restaurants and they are unique & delish. The other dishes are good too. More expensive than Thai Express (unless you get the lunch special or bento) yet worth it.

Definitely a fan! Other outlets are at Ridgewood, Thomson, Tanjong Katong and Robertson Quay and now there is also one close to my office!!Well close...it's actually a 10 minute walk from the nearest MRT station through a blistering heat. Then most of the time I get there, there is only a place outside for me to sit. Most people leave office around 12 for lunch in the neighboring offices, meaning they arrive there at 12:15-12:30, that's when the place start to get packed. For a reason though, because the food is just so good! E-sarn never fails to let me know if I grave for pad thai or green curry (although I don't really know what the figs are doing inside the curry and none of my collegues seem to eat them as well). They have a good set lunch menu for 7.90, see picture! Service is fast as well. The mango sticky rice with icecream on top is just heaven, but the same price as the set menu all together so take note. All together, great place to have lunch, but beat the crowd!

This is our VERY favorite restaurant in Singapore.  We love Thai food, and this place doesn't disappoint.  Crispy soft shell crab, curries and pad thai are our favorites.  I love prawns and even though it's not on the menu, they will make sweet and sour prawns for me.  The prawns are not deep fried, which makes it a lot healthier and it always tastes wonderful. The service is pretty good here too, and for Singapore that's saying a lot.  They are always on top of orders, get food out efficiently and usually at the same time as everyone at the table.  We drive half way across the island for this place.  Hands down the best Thai food in town.

address: 6 Jalan Bukit Merah Lane #01-105 Singapore 150006 Singapore
comment: Cheap and good prawn noodles. One of the few stalls with "A" for cleanliness and food hygiene.

Decor is simple but the food is affordable and good!! Very crowded on weekday lunch and weekend dinner. So it's good to come during Sunday lunch!My favorites include:* Green Curry* Pandan Chicken* Prawn Omelette * Tom Yam Soup* Pork BasilThere's a public carpark behind that's accessible by a small lane called Jalan Pelepah. If that is full, you can try parking at the landed property. Just be careful.

I have a general rule for Thai restaurants. If there's a picture of the King, it must be good (probably because it's manned by Real Thai People). This place has a big picture of the King (and the Queen), but it's the least good place I've found so far with a picture of Bhumibol. Not that the food is bad, but it isn't particularly good.This place is a rather no-frills joint, which you can tell from the laminated menus, which are battered and have the lamination peeling from them.The Tom Sapp (sic - Tom Sapp seems to be someone's name and the dish is called Tom Saap) was quite good, with a generous amount of ingredients, but was very very spicy. It was so spicy it made my lips sting.The Thai fish cake was truly freshly made and the freshness could be tasted, in contrast to places that do this frozen.Oriental fried rice was rather disappointing. It was rice fried with onion, frozen mixed vegetables, a middling amount of meat and a touch of ketchup. The taste was okay but not great and it lacked character.The honey chicken portion was a bit small, but I prefer smaller dishes since you get to try more things. It was thickly coated in a prawn paste batter (which seemed weird) and was well fried. Though it didn't have much honey it was tasty.The Thai iced tea was a disappointment because it was too dilute even at the start, even before all the ice melted.This place has no air conditioning, which combined with the spicy food seems designed to make you order more drinks. That said it was only $40 despite all the above, 2 Thai iced teas and a coconut.Though the food is good enough, E-Sarn across the road is better (though more expensive).

I'm definitely a fan of this place! Good food at reasonable prices. Ordered the Tom Yam Soup, Green Curry, Honey Chicken and the Kang Kong Thai Style which were all very delicious. The soup was really tasty and it paired really well with the fried honey chicken that was sweet. Service was good as well. Overall, a pleasant experience and I would certainly visit this place in the future.

Food:Pizzas were pretty decent. The dough base was actually quite tasty, and cooked with a bit of charring so it can be crispy at some areas. It's thin enough to not become chewy, yet it's thick enough to not break or tear. They cook their pizzas in this large oven (although idk if it's gas or wood/charcoal fired) Overall the pizzas were flavourful, and the toppings were relatively substantial. They also have quite a variety of options, from veggie-only to pepperoni (duh), including "pizza staples" like Quad formaggi. Had the carbonara and squid ink pasta too, and the pasta is quite decent as well. Not soggy, and the pasta had some bite. The gravy on both occasions was quite thick and tasty too. Ambience:Relatively nice place to pamper yourself if you want to treat yourself to a decent meal. There's alfresco dining if you wish, and it's sheltered too. Music is not too loud yet discernible to enjoy (in case you ran out of conversations)Price:There's a $15 lunch set which is pretty worth it. Personal pizza/pasta + drink (green tea/coke) + salad (with vinaigrette dressing). However, be prepared to pay $20ish per person if ordering a la carte. Overall:Service is quite efficient and food came relatively fast. Been here twice, and enjoyed the food each time. Would bring visitors here to have lunch in the future - not as expensive yet still have the feel of a decent restaurant.

I'm stoked that Peperoni has opened very near where I live! They serve up tasty pizzas and pastas.This is a bio-tech business park, so its fairly empty at night after office hours. So, service is quick and at least for now, there's plenty of seating. It's kid-friendly too - there's a playground right outside.We always order 1 Family Sized/XXL pizza and some sides. The large pizza's great value; get it half and half so there's variety. I usually spend about $25 per person here.

So grateful for this comfort food haven at such a convenient location!! Lunch crowd - overwhelming. Lunch deal - very worth it. If in a rush, get the pasta not the pizza. When there are large groups, they tend to go for pizza and it takes a long time to get the big pizzas out. And in turn, small ones are slow too. You get 10% off when you order online for takeaway. Also you can personalize your drinks and salad for the lunch deal. Definitely get a large or extra large pizza because you can get two flavors on one. You can only match similar sauce based pizzas. My favorite pizzas here are the bacon Miele, salmone, frutti Di made, prosciutto arugula, pancetta (with the egg). The funghi is also really good for vegetarians. For pasta, I always go with linguine and carbonara. It is the cream sauced version but it is still satisfying. Just thicken the sauce by sprinkling endless amounts of cheese!!! Lemon tea house made is always my go to drink. Love it!! The beer however seems really watered down. There are good deals for jugs but the tastes seem rather off. Get the bottled beer if you want a good one. The managers are the only reliable ones at this branch. The lady behind the cashier/bar and the floor manager are great to go to. The other servers are typical Singaporean, oblivious. If you don't want to stink, sit al fresco. The music is also rather loud, but has a good selection of 80s mix.

There are some days when the American in me is craving a good 'ol thin crust pepperoni pizza, and Peperoni does it just about right. I like how the crust is quite thin, yet it holds up to the sauce and cheese without getting soggy. The pepperoni is flavorful yet not too oily with a good ratio of pepperoni to other ingredients.If Diavola (pepperoni) isn't your thing, there are also other classic options like Margherita, Funghi (mushroom), Quattro Formaggi (cheese), or Hawaiana (pineapple and ham) plus pastas or salads of course. Pretty much something for everyone. The lunch set is not a bad deal at S$14.90 nett for a drink, pizza, and salad.

What an incredible find just outside the frantic Orchard Blvd area. Conveniently located across from Tanglin Mall and easily accessible by foot, bus, or taxi. A short 20 minute walk from Tang Plaza MRT. Food, service, and atmosphere were top notch this evening. Menu consists of classics from the heart of Tuscany to the Almafi coast. Pizza, pasta, fish, meat , and salads are all represented. The complimentary bruschetta was excellent. Instead of a thick slice of traditional baguette, they use more of a local crisped flat bread topped with seasoned chopped tomatoes and herbs. I could eat a whole plate myself. Their Frito misto is not one that will soon be forgotten. fresh and flavorful prawns, local fish, and calamari lightly fried. Accompanied by garlic aioli and a vibrant marinara sauce. Fantastic appetizer. Caprese was so much better than I was expecting because I haven't seen a decent tomato since I arrived in Singapore. This place is the exception. Deep red ripened tomatoes, soft mozzarella, basil and extra virgin olive oil. Very enjoyable. For our main we shared a pizza Margherita. Expertly fired, thin Neapolitan style crust, simply topped with red sauce, mozzarella , and basil. Excellent desserts available, but we chose a liquid option to finish things off. Grappa Nonino and Amaro Montenegro rounded things off for us. Outstanding. Attentive servers, expansive outdoor seating, and excellent food make this a top choice for Italian fare in Singapore.

Simple, well done, southern-Italian food. If I don't feel like cooking, this is the next best thing! Nice location, good service, and all considered fairly priced (for Singapore, in this neighborhood...)

We came here to celebrate a birthday. It's slightly upmarket - a still or sparkling water kind of place. We had a fairly attentive waiter, though he did once miss refilling our glasses.Don't be put off by the relatively high price of the appetisers, the portions are correspondingly generous. Our pastas and pizzas were all well done. Not too salty, very fresh and comfortingly homely.Overall, quite satisfying but slightly pricey.

This seemed like a legitimate Southern Italian trattoria. The food was all fresh and simple. The seafood stew was great and about $12 cheaper than the normal ~$30 it tends to cost elsewhere (e.g. Pasta Brava). The spaghetti amatriciana was very nice. The best thing was the ribeye steak though with mushrooms and potatoes, which was extremely well seasoned and cooked and seemed like a lot of food. This is easily the best steak I have seen in Singapore at that price point. They also have gelato from Alfero, which is amazing. I will probably bring my family here when they visit.Service was a little avoidant but the food was good enough to make up for it. Only real shocker when the bill came was that the focaccia (pizza bianca) cost $12.80. It was really good and possibly worth it, but that is disproportionately expensive relative to the other items.
Food was delicious. Prices reasonable. Staff were quite nice. Would readily recommend.

Very friendly service, gave great recommendations. Garlic bread was fantastic. We got pasta with clams and pasta with prawns, both tasted amazing, and I got a lot of clams. And we finished it of with tartufo affogato, rounding out a fantastic meal.

There is a chill in the air when it comes to service at this restaurant.  Dined on a Saturday around 7:20pm slightly ahead of our reservation time. .  As it was early the dining room was empty.  We were seated quickly and provided menus.  A female member of the wait staff asked if we wanted a beverage.  WE ARE NON DRINKERS so we said water would be fine.The waiter comes over to our table and my partner and I ordered Tortelloni and Lasagna for our mains.  Again we were asked if we wanted wine or cocktaI with our meals.  Again we politely stated water would be fine and that we would be adding dessert at the end.The decision of no wine or cocktail did not sit well with our server.  He took a bottle off the table and presented our order to the kitchen.  Food arrived promptly but no follow up from our server.There were additional staff on the floor whose jobs it seems was to wisk plates off the table but all it felt like, as a customer,  was rushed service.  THE FOOD IS FANTASTIC.  It is a shame that all the effort is offset at  the front of the house.When we finished our entres we decided to close out our check and leave as fast as we could.  We went up the street for an after dinner coffee and dessert.  We did hear a few voices saying good night on our way out of the door.This was our second time visiting this dining spot.  The first time was a late night coffee and dessert.  That time also the food was very good but the reception staff was short and unwelcoming.Twice is enough for Lafiandra.  There are alot of excellent mid priced Italian eateries in Singapore to spend our money.A word of note to wait staff.  We were two business men dining with company support.  Support does not mean they cover wine and spirits.  That is okay by use as we are former spirit consumers.  I know it lends to a lower check but we should not be made to feel less than welcome because of it.

Greeted by a lovely Italian waitress the moment I walked in. Love the environment. Can be quite crowded on a Friday night. I suggest you make reservations. Ordered one of their baked pasta (good), garlic bread (good), salad (good), and risotto (quite bland after having all the other flavorful dishes).One of the waitress doesn't look that happy though. But overall, loved that place.
Outstanding Italian food, service was impeccable and prices were SG reasonable.   First time there tonight and we will be back as other SG Italian restaurants do not even compare!   Nice job!

Am giving it a four star cos I didn't had enough time to try their dessert but I'm pretty sure this is a five star restaurant. My friend and I had about an hour to spare for dinner before rushing off to a nearby venue to catch a performance. It was a wet and dreary friday evening around 630pm. The restaurant was actually pretty empty but the atmosphere was still warm and cosy cos of the lighting and deco.
